tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires calculating natural frequencies, which involves setting up equations of motion and solving for eigenvalues. It requires understanding of vibration concepts and linear algebra, making it a medium difficulty problem. It also integrates concepts from dynamics and vibration.

answer_validation.reasoning: The system consists of two masses m1 and m2 on a frictionless surface connected only by a single spring of stiffness k between them, with no springs to ground. Hence a rigid-body motion where both masses translate together without changing the spring length has zero restoring force, giving one natural frequency of 0. For the vibratory mode, let x1 and x2 be displacements of m1 and m2. The spring force is k(x2 - x1). Taking positive to the right, equations of motion are m1 x1'' = k(x2 - x1) and m2 x2'' = -k(x2 - x1). Rearranging: m1 x1'' + k(x1 - x2) = 0 and m2 x2'' + k(x2 - x1) = 0. Assume harmonic motion x1 = X1 e^{i\omega t}, x2 = X2 e^{i\omega t}. This yields the algebraic system: (-m1 \omega^2 + k) X1 - k X2 = 0 and -k X1 + (-m2 \omega^2 + k) X2 = 0. For non-trivial solutions, determinant must vanish: (-m1 \omega^2 + k)(-m2 \omega^2 + k) - k^2 = 0. Expanding: m1 m2 \omega^4 - k(m1 + m2) \omega^2 = 0. Factorizing: \omega^2 (m1 m2 \omega^2 - k(m1 + m2)) = 0. Thus \omega_1 = 0 and \omega_2^2 = k(m1 + m2)/(m1 m2). This matches option A.

step_by_step: Step 1: Interpret the system: two masses m1 and m2 on a frictionless surface connected only by a spring k between them; no ground springs, so there is a rigid-body mode.
Step 2: Define coordinates x1 and x2 as horizontal displacements of m1 and m2 from equilibrium, positive to the right.
Step 3: Write spring force: F_s = k(x2 - x1), acting on m1 to the right and on m2 to the left.
Step 4: Apply Newton's second law: m1 x1'' = k(x2 - x1) and m2 x2'' = -k(x2 - x1). Rearrange to standard form.
Step 5: Assume harmonic solutions x1 = X1 e^{i\omega t}, x2 = X2 e^{i\omega t} and substitute to obtain algebraic equations in X1, X2.
Step 6: Form the coefficient matrix and set its determinant to zero to obtain the characteristic equation in \omega^2.
Step 7: Solve the characteristic equation to find \omega^2 = 0 and \omega^2 = k(m1 + m2)/(m1 m2), giving natural frequencies 0 and \sqrt{k(m1 + m2)/(m1 m2)}.

topic.name: Mechanical vibrations of multi-degree-of-freedom systems
topic.syllabus_ref: Vibration of beams and structures; multi degree of freedom systems

concepts.name: Equations of motion using Newton's law

essential: Newton's second law and free-body diagrams
Matrix form of equations of motion for multi-degree-of-freedom systems
Concept of natural frequency and mode shapes
helpful: Physical interpretation of rigid-body motion vs deformational modes

Main Concept: requires: Setting up equations of motion using Newton's law
enables: Analysis of higher DOF structural vibration problems
enables: Design and tuning of vibration absorbers and dynamic systems

difficulty_factors: Requires recognizing presence of a zero-frequency rigid-body mode
Needs comfort with forming and solving a 2x2 determinant for eigenvalues

textbook_references.author: William T. Thomson, Marie Dillon Dahleh

video_references.professor: Prof. S.K. Dwivedy and Prof. Rajiv Tiwari
video_references.topic_covered: Derivation of equations of motion and natural frequencies for a 2-DOF mass-spring system

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Model system \rightarrow Write equations of motion \rightarrow Assume harmonic motion \rightarrow Form eigenvalue problem \rightarrow Solve characteristic equation
key_insights: Because there is no connection to ground, one mode must be rigid-body with zero frequency.
The non-zero natural frequency depends on both masses and the single spring, leading to an effective reduced mass.

formulas_principles.name: Newton's second law
formulas_principles.conditions: Applied to each mass along the direction of motion
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to derive equations of motion for each mass

formulas_principles.name: Hooke's law for the connecting spring
formulas_principles.conditions: Linear spring, force proportional to relative displacement
formulas_principles.relevance: Gives coupling force between the two masses

formulas_principles.name: Eigenvalue condition for natural frequencies
formulas_principles.conditions: Undamped free vibration of linear MDOF systems
formulas_principles.relevance: Determines allowable \omega for non-trivial mode shapes

formulas_principles.name: Non-zero natural frequency of two masses connected by a single spring
formulas_principles.conditions: Two masses on frictionless surface connected only by one spring
formulas_principles.relevance: Final expression matching the correct option

industry_examples: Relative vibration of two spacecraft modules connected by a docking mechanism modeled as a spring
Lateral vibration of two rail cars connected by a coupler with elastic characteristics
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Understanding coupled mass-spring natural frequencies helps predict and avoid resonant relative motions that can cause fatigue or failure in connections between components.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming both masses are attached to ground springs and using SDOF formula $\omega = \sqrt{k/m}$ with some equivalent mass.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They overlook that the only spring is between the masses and there is no direct stiffness to ground, so they default to familiar single-mass models.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always redraw the system and explicitly mark which nodes are connected to ground and which are only connected to other masses.
common_mistakes.consequence: Misses the zero-frequency rigid-body mode and yields completely wrong non-zero frequency.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting the zero natural frequency and reporting only the non-zero one.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They associate natural frequency only with oscillatory motion and ignore rigid-body motion.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Check if the entire system can translate without deforming any spring; if yes, include a zero-frequency mode.
common_mistakes.consequence: Eliminates all options with a zero frequency, leading to incorrect choice.

common_mistakes.mistake: Sign errors in the coupling terms of the equations of motion, such as writing $m_1 x_1'' + k(x_2 + x_1) = 0$.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusion about direction of spring forces on each mass.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Systematically draw free-body diagrams and note that the same spring force acts in opposite directions on the two masses.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to an incorrect stiffness matrix and wrong characteristic equation.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: If the whole system can slide freely without stretching springs, there is a zero natural frequency (rigid-body mode).
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When inspecting multi-mass spring systems for rigid-body modes.

flashcards.front: For two masses $m_1$, $m_2$ connected only by a spring $k$ on a frictionless surface, what are the natural frequencies?
When does a multi-DOF spring-mass system have a zero natural frequency?
flashcards.back: When there exists a rigid-body motion where all masses move together without deforming any spring (no restoring force).

flashcards.front: Write the equations of motion for two masses $m_1$, $m_2$ connected by a spring $k$ with displacements $x_1$, $x_2$.
What quick check ensures you included all modes (including rigid-body) in a spring-mass system?
flashcards.back: Ask: Can the system move as a whole without stretching any spring? If yes, add a zero-frequency mode to your list.

real_world_context.application: Relative motion of connected spacecraft modules
real_world_context.industry_example: Two modules of the ISS connected by a flexible joint can be approximated as two masses with an elastic connection; their relative vibration frequency is given by the same formula.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect prediction of relative vibration can lead to misalignment or structural fatigue in docking mechanisms.

real_world_context.industry_example: Two train cars connected by a coupler behave like masses linked by a spring; understanding their coupled frequencies helps design smoother ride and avoid resonance.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Resonant relative motion can cause high impact loads on couplers and cargo.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Notice it is a standard 2-DOF spring-mass system with symmetric masses and one spring; set up 2 equations or recall the known result. Should be solvable in under 2 minutes.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If you recognize a free-sliding system with one spring, immediately pick the option with 0 and a frequency proportional to $\sqrt{k}$ and inversely to both masses (i.e., involving $m_1 m_2$ in denominator).
exam_strategy.time_management: Spend at most 2–3 minutes; if algebra is taking too long, check for the zero mode and use dimensional reasoning to eliminate wrong options.

search_keywords: two degree of freedom spring mass system natural frequencies
rigid body mode zero natural frequency
coupled oscillators two masses one spring
eigenvalues stiffness and mass matrix vibrations
GATE AE vibrations multi degree of freedom

alternative_methods.name: Center-of-mass and relative coordinate method
alternative_methods.description: Introduce coordinates: center-of-mass motion X and relative displacement q = x2 - x1. The COM coordinate X has no restoring force, giving \omega = 0 directly. The relative coordinate q behaves as a single-degree-of-freedom system with effective mass m_eq = (m1 m2)/(m1 + m2) and stiffness k, giving \omega^2 = k/m_eq = k(m1 + m2)/(m1 m2).
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Gives strong physical insight into rigid-body and deformational modes; algebra is simpler. Cons: Requires recognizing appropriate coordinate transformation.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when the system obviously has a rigid-body mode and symmetry suggests COM-relative coordinates.

connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Similar eigenvalue problems appear when finding natural modes of aircraft longitudinal and lateral motion.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: State-space models of coupled systems use the same eigenvalue analysis to determine system poles.
connections_to_other_subjects.Space Dynamics: Relative motion of spacecraft components connected by flexible elements uses analogous vibration models.

deeper_dive_topics: Mode shapes and orthogonality in multi-degree-of-freedom systems
Effect of damping on coupled oscillators and complex eigenvalues
Modal analysis and coordinate transformation to decouple equations
Vibration absorbers and tuned mass dampers based on 2-DOF models

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Multi-degree-of-freedom systems; natural frequencies and modes
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Excellent representative question testing basic 2-DOF vibration modeling and recognition of rigid-body modes.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided general vibration concepts and examples of 2-DOF systems and natural frequency derivations, which align with the method used here, but did not cover this exact configuration. Core derivation relied mainly on standard internal knowledge.

future_questions_potential: Ask for mode shapes corresponding to the two natural frequencies for the same system.
Modify the system by adding a ground spring to one mass and ask for new natural frequencies.
Introduce damping between the masses and ask for the characteristic equation or damping ratio.
Ask to compute the effective reduced mass for the relative motion coordinate and interpret its meaning.
